post.content:
Leme and the University of Chicago visit community facilities in Maré 

Leme and the University of Chicago carried out a series of visits to community facilities in Maré with the goal of closely learning about initiatives focused on violence prevention and the protection of young people in vulnerable contexts. The visits were guided by Thaís Custódio, associate researcher at Leme, PhD candidate in Economics at PPGE UFRJ, and master in Regional Economics at PPGER UFRRJ. 

The agenda featured the presence of Chris Blattman, economist and professor at the University of Chicago, who took part in the activities organized by Leme during his visit to Brazil. Blattman’s visit was coordinated by Júlia Guerra, Leme’s director and co-founder and a PhD candidate in Public Administration and Government at FGV EAESP, who initiated the arrangements while the researcher was still in Chicago. The visit also included Benjamin Lessing; researchers Alexandre Simões and Moustafa El-Kashlan, from the University of Chicago; and, representing Leme, Isabela Salgado, a researcher at the laboratory, and Ana Paula Pellegrino, an associate researcher.

The visits aimed to understand the local dynamics of criminal group activities and their relationships with young residents in these territories. During the agenda, the institutions visited presented their projects and strategies in the field of public security and social prevention. 

The team was welcomed by Ricardo Fernandes, founder and coordinator of Instituto Movimentos, Raquel Willadino and Milena Afonso, director and coordinator of Observatório de Favelas, along with the Direito à Vida team, Lidiane Malanquini and Liliane Santos, coordinator and researcher at Redes da Maré, accompanied by the Direito à  Segurança Pública e Acesso à Justiça team, and Luciana Alves and Roberto Custódio, coordinators of the Special Project Luta pela Paz. 

During the meeting, each organization shared its experiences and methodologies, showing different ways of working within the territory both directly and indirectly to promote opportunities and address violence. 

The visit allowed Leme to deepen its dialogue with local actors and bring academic knowledge production closer to community practices, reinforcing the laboratory’s commitment to evidence based public policy and the recognition of local prevention initiatives. 

In addition, the organizations committed to sharing studies and data on the topic, strengthening the exchange of knowledge and cooperation in favor of a more inclusive and effective public security approach.
